The Palmetto Cluster is a group of computers on Clemson's campus. These computers are much more powerful than your laptop or even desktops in the lab. Running computational chemistry calculations requires the use of these powerful computers. For research, you will log into the Palmetto Cluster remotely. ## Logging in 1. Open your termial (Terminal on Macs, PowerShell on Windows) 2. Type **`ssh [username]@slogin.palmetto.clemson.edu`** 3. Enter your password This logs you in to a computer called the "login node". "Node" is a computing term for a single computational unit within a cluster of computers. ## Directory Structure and Creating Files Just as your laptop has folders and files, you can create folders and files on Palmetto. In computing, folders are called directories. 1. Make a new directory to store your tutorials. **`mkdir tutorials`** 2. To check your work, type **`ls`** to list all directories and files. You should see `tutorials`. 3. Make a file in the tutorials directory. First, move into that directory. **`cd tutorials`** 4. What would you see if you typed **`ls`** here? Try it to check your understanding. 5. To open a new file called `my_file`, type **`vim my_file`** This opens a new file with an editor called `vim`. 6. To write in this file, press `a` for `append`. Then begin typing a phrase. 7. Once you have finished typing, press `esc` to leave editing mode. 8. To save and close your file, type `:wq`. `w` is for `write` (or save) and `q` is for `quit`. ## Check your understanding

If you were to type ls here, what would you see?

9. Now, let's add to the file. Paste the following text into `my_file`. To paste, open the file, type `a`, and right-click paste. Save and close using `:wq`. 10. There are a few options for viewing the contents of this file. - Use cat to view all contents. `cat my_file` - Use tail to view the end of the file. `tail my_file` - Use head to view the beginning of the file. `head my_file` 11.
